title: How Knowledge is Created:  The Shroud of Turin
post: It is not a huge revelation that we all filter information according to our world view, our preconceived ideas and opinions.  It is standard psychology that information that conflicts with our world view creates cognitive dissonance and must either be rejected (most likely) or accepted and integrated (less likely).  For those who hold strong opinions, conflicting information must be very persuasive to effect a change in that opinion.  We cannot tolerate being in a state of confusion so we form opinions that integrates information in accordance with our world view and rejects everything else.  The white lab coat of pure objectivity is an illusion.  Everyone has a bias and no one has all the information available on a given topic. This is exactly why the legal system of prosecutor and defense with 12 jurors is so important.  Not only will both lawyers present radically different views of the facts it is now up to 12 individuals to come to a reasoned consensus.  Each juror heard something different from the testimony of witnesses and evidence presented by both sides.  It is the closest we will ever get to the truth–and even then they get it wrong from time to time.  I have often said that when it comes to the Shroud, we cannot get to a verdict that is “beyond a reasonable doubt” as in a criminal trial.  However, I believe the “preponderance of evidence” will support authenticity.  But then again, thats my opinion based on my world view!
author: Russ Breault

title: How Knowledge is Created:  The Shroud of Turin
post: How knowledge is created? What if it is not created and comes in the form of intuitive knowledge, generated spontaneously, coming as though by accident? In this case the question of objectivity does not arise. Why? Because the knowledge comes spontaneously, it is not chosen and can come in the form of bad news. It leads to insight.
